Here's the fixed method with the error resolved:

```java
@org.junit.jupiter.params.ParameterizedTest
@org.junit.jupiter.params.provider.ValueSource(strings = { "", ".0", "*", "Ãª", "-my-tag", // @checkstyle LineLengthCheck (1 line)
"" })
void shouldFailToGetValueWhenInvalid(final java.lang.String original) {
    final com.artipie.docker.Tag.Valid tag = new com.artipie.docker.Tag.Valid(original);
    org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(tag.valid(), new org.hamcrest.core.IsEqual(false));
    java.lang.Throwable throwable = org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.assertThrows(com.artipie.docker.error.InvalidTagNameException.class, tag::value);
    org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(throwable.getMessage(), org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.allOf(org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.<java.lang.String>containsString(original), org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.containsString("Invalid tag")));
}
```

The error was caused by a missing `new` keyword before the `org.hamcrest.core.StringContains.CoreStringContains(original)` invocation. I have replaced it with `org.hamcrest.CoreMatchers.containsString(original)` which is a shortcut for the same functionality provided by `org.hamcrest.core.StringContains.CoreStringContains`.
